title: Family's heartache after young dad died 'belly flopping' from pier into icy sea 'for a laugh'
text:
News Family's heartache after young dad died 'belly flopping' from pier into icy sea 'for a laugh' Dale Smith, 27, broke his neck instantly after jumping off Cleethorpes Pier - and now his mum is warning others about the dangers Share Factory supervisor Dale Smith died instantly (Photo: SWNS) Share   
A grieving mum whose son died after "belly flopping" from a pier into the icy sea has urged others: “Don’t be silly after a night out because it could prove fatal.” 
Dad-of-four Dale Smith, 27, jumped off a pier into the shallow Humber estuary "just for a laugh" while "skinny dipping" after a night out. 
But but the water wasn't deep enough and he died instantly from a broken neck, an inquest into his death heard. 
His grieving mum Lisa Taylor said at the hearing: “Don’t be silly after a night out and jump into water because it could prove fatal.” 
Dale, from Grimsby, was out with Lisa's other other son, Joshua Taylor, and his girlfriend Natasha Harvey when he “belly flopped” into the water, rather than going in head first. Dale was a loving dad to four children (Photo: SWNS) 
Assistant coroner for Grimsby and North Lincolnshire Jane Eatock concluded the death was due to "misadventure”, the Grimsby Telegraph reported . 
Explaining to relatives gathered at Cleethorpes Town Hall, she said: “In a sense it is an accidental death by putting himself in harm’s way.” 
She passed her condolences to the relatives and said: “It is tragic to lose some one at such a young age.” 
The assistant coroner praised rescuers who ran to help Mr Smith after he plunged into the water off Cleethorpes Pier on July 17 last year. 
Joshua had pulled his brother out of the water while Natasha rang 999. Two doormen from a nearby nightspot ran to give first aid. 
The inquest heard Dale and his brother jumped into the water from a slipway near to the pier in a “skinny dipping” adventure. 
Dale had consumed about seven pints of lager during the night out. Dale's family and friends at Cleethorpes beach (Photo: SWNS) 
The level of alcohol in his system was estimated to be around between two and three times the drink-drive limit. 
The assistant coroner said: “That impairs your ability to think sensibly and rationally.” 
In tribute, Joshua described Dale as a loving father to his four children and a hard-working man. 
He worked a soup production factory as a supervisor, a job he had done for around three years. 
Joshua said: “He liked a drink at the weekend. There was never a dull moment with him. I always looked up to him.” 
He told the inquest Dale had taught him to swim. 
He said: “He liked being in and around water. Many years ago he had jumped into water and broke his arm.” 
The brother said the two of them had been drinking at home before going out to pubs before visiting two nightclubs. Dale's family want others to learn from the tragedy (Photo: SWNS) 
Joshua said Dale had overheard someone talking about “skinny dipping” and he decided to go across the road to the slipway down to the water. 
He added: “We both got stripped off. Dale dived in and I went in after him. 
“I could not tell how deep it was. It was cold. There were a few people about. It was just for a laugh.” 
He described how he slipped and ended up belly flopping into the water. 
He told the inquest the next thing he saw was his brother floating face down. 
Natasha said the tide had not come right in and it was difficult to tell how deep the water was. 
She told how after watching her boyfriend belly flop, he stood up in the water. 
PC Carol Rayton said ambulance crews arrived quickly but there was nothing paramedics could do to revive Dale. Read More Baby died 28 minutes after being born as parents blame 'systematic failures' for tragedy 
The assistant coroner praised his brother and his girlfriend and the two doormen who ran to help. 
She said: "Credit to you for doing something as quickly as you did. I hope you take something from that. 
“Credit to the people who came to the rescue and they were helped by passersby and the two doormen and the hospital staff did everything they could. Sadly there was nothing that could be done.” 
She added: “He was putting himself in a dangerous situation.” 
After the hearing Lisa said her children had been her support during the tragedy. 
She said: “Dale loved his kids. He loved life.” 
She has told her surviving children never to jump into the water after being out drinking. 
Dale’s newborn nephew, born 13 weeks ago, has been named Isaac Dale Robin Dixon in his uncle’s memory. 
The tragedy on Cleethorpes beach came less than three months after Lisa lost her husband Jeff Smith, who had a heart attack as he headed to Wembley stadium to watch Grimsby Town play. Following the hearing, the Maritime and Coastguard Agency said: “The coastguard would like to encourage everyone to enjoy our British coastline safely. 
“So, make sure that you check weather and tides before you set out, wear appropriate clothing and footwear, be responsible about alcohol consumption and go to a lifeguarded beach. Stay within the flagged area and listen to the advice of lifeguards. 
“Jumping from piers, cliffs, rocks or other structures into the sea can be very dangerous. The depth of the water can dramatically change with the tide and what was a deep pool at lunchtime might be a shallow puddle by teatime. 
"You don’t know what hazards may be lurking under the surface until you are hurt or worse." Like us on Facebook
